title: Bob Taylor (rugby league)
text:
Robert "Bob" Taylor ( – death unknown) was an English professional <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> footballer who played in the 1910s, 1920s and 1930s. He played at representative level for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a>, <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> and <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Lancashire</a>, and at club level for <a href="Barrow%20Raiders">Barrow</a> (two spells) and <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull FC</a>, as a , i.e. number 11 or 12, during the era of contested <a href="Scrum%20%28rugby%29%23Rugby%20league">scrum</a>s.
Background.
Bob Taylor was born on the <a href="Furness">Furness</a> peninsula, <a href="Lancashire">Lancashire</a>, England.
Playing career.
International honours.
Taylor won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">England</a> while at Hull in 1921 against Australia, in 1922 against Wales, in 1923 against Wales, in 1925 against Wales (2 matches), and in 1926 against Wales, and <a href="Other%20Nationalities%20rugby%20league%20team">Other Nationalities</a>, and won <a href="Cap%20%28sport%29">cap</a>s for <a href="Great%20Britain%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Great Britain</a> while at Hull in 1921–22 against Australia, and in 1926–27 against New Zealand.
County honours.
Taylor represented <a href="Rugby%20League%20War%20of%20the%20Roses">Lancashire</a> while at Hull, and is one of only four players to do so, they are; <a href="Ellis%20Clarkson">Ellis Clarkson</a>, Bob Taylor, <a href="Dick%20Gemmell">Dick Gemmell</a> and <a href="Steve%20Prescott">Steve Prescott</a>.
Challenge Cup Final appearances.
Taylor played right-, i.e. number 12, and scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull FC</a>'s 9-10 defeat by <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a> in the <a href="1922%20Challenge%20Cup">1922</a> <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> Final during the <a href="1921%E2%80%9322%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20Union%20season%23Challenge%20Cup">1921–22 season</a> at <a href="Headingley%20Stadium%23Rugby%20ground">Headingley</a> <a href="Headingley%20Rugby%20Stadium">Rugby Stadium</a>, <a href="Leeds">Leeds</a>, in front of a crowd of 34,827. <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> were just one-point behind <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a> when Bob Taylor scored a <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">try</a> in the dying minutes, however <a href="Billy%20Stone%20%28rugby%20league%29">Billy Stone</a> was unable to score the <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">conversion</a> and <a href="Rochdale%20Hornets">Rochdale Hornets</a> won the <a href="1922%20Challenge%20Cup">1922 Challenge Cup</a>.
Club career.
Bob Taylor scored 32 <a href="Try%20%28rugby%29">tries</a> in 35 appearances during the <a href="1925%E2%80%9326%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1925–26 season</a>, this was the "most tries scored in a <a href="Rugby%20Football%20League">Rugby Football League</a> season by a <a href="Rugby%20league%20positions%23Forwards">forward</a>" record, until this was extended to 40 tries by <a href="Bob%20Haigh">Bob Haigh</a> of <a href="Leeds%20Rhinos">Leeds</a> during the <a href="1970%E2%80%9371%20Northern%20Rugby%20Football%20League%20season">1970–71 season</a>.
Club career.
Bob Taylor was the father of the rugby league footballer who played in the 1940s for <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull FC</a>; , and the rugby league footballer who played for <a href="Hull%20F.C.">Hull F.C.</a> (<a href="Reserve%20team">A-Team</a>); .
